newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul stocks close lower after early rebound.
newsitem.headline: Seoul stocks close lower after early rebound.

text.p: Seoul stocks closed lower on Monday after selling in the afternoon more than offset the rebound in the late morning session, brokers said.
They said selling increased in the afternoon because of the disappointment among investors at the lack of fresh news from the meeting between the President and economic ministers.
"Investors who hoped for new steps to help revive the economy were disappointed at the results from the meeting and sold shares," said Koh Soon-shik of LG Securities.
The composite index closed at 750.82, down 5.85 points from the previous close.

The Ministry of Finance and Economy said it would allow local firms buying more than 50 percent of their machinery purchases from domestic manufacturers to borrow up to $2 billion in foreign loans next year.
But this was just a follow-up to an earlier announcement.
President Kim Young-sam told his ministers to make efforts to reduce next year's current account deficit to half of the level for this year. But he did not elaborate.
"The news on President Kim's remarks also failed to impress investors," said Koh.
Brokers said initial public offerings by nine companies, due Tuesday and Wednesday, also hurt the buying sentiment as investors expected funds to outflow from the market for the offerings.
Nine companies will receive subscriptions for their 448 billion won worth of new shares for the two days.
Decliners beat advancers by 619 to 254, with 130 stocks closing unchanged. Volume were a low 22.48 million shares.
The index futures December contracts closed 0.55 points lower at 80.15 and the KOSPI-200 index ended 0.66 points down to 79.02. --YOO CHOON-SIK (822) 727 5646
